body_html:
The dataset pipeline doesn't do anything special with strings, and relies on tensorflow::Tensor refcounting to release the data.

@sushanthku Can you try making a tf.constant() string from a representative line in your file, and running tf.string_split() on that constant in a loop to see if the memory growth is similar?
body_text:
The dataset pipeline doesn't do anything special with strings, and relies on tensorflow::Tensor refcounting to release the data.
@sushanthku Can you try making a tf.constant() string from a representative line in your file, and running tf.string_split() on that constant in a loop to see if the memory growth is similar?
body:
The dataset pipeline doesn't do anything special with strings, and relies on `tensorflow::Tensor` refcounting to release the data. 

@sushanthku Can you try making a `tf.constant()` string from a representative line in your file, and running `tf.string_split()` on that constant in a loop to see if the memory growth is similar?
